ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned new vocabulary every now and then and several new Chinese characters.
Advanced reading/listening/speaking Korean skills alongside contemporary lifestyle in Korea.
i learned more hanja and more advanced korean words
I learned about the current culture of Korea, and developed skills in "hanja" of Korean language.

Even though Korean is my first language, this class taught me how to strengthen my oral and written skills. I also learned a lot of new vocabulary, and I felt as though each term I learned was appropriate for the skill level of the students in the class as well as very practical.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The professor is absolutely wonderful and keeps the level of engagement very high throughout the semester.
the course was very well structured and was very interactive. it was also a very manageable workload and professor lim was very fun and helpful

I like how fluid and flexible the overall course was, with engaging material that were actually interesting and relevant to learn about. I think an improvement could be more class discussions, since everyone is pretty fluent in the language already.

The strength of this course was the professor! I loved his teaching style, his humor, everything about the way he led the course. Professor Lim is very caring, a wonderful instructor, and my favorite professor at Yale so far. The only thing I can think about is maybe incorporating more writing activities, but I also felt like we had a decent amount and I personally just enjoy writing more than the average student might.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you want to take a low-stress class with a fun and kind professor
Yes! If you are a student looking to advance your proficiency in Korean, I would highly recommend!
yes, especially if you have a strong background in Korean. the material you learn is very applicable to the modern-day, so the things you talk about are very fun
Yes, it's really fun and your Korean will improve a lot.

Yes, I think this class is a wonderful way to get to learn about not just the history of Korea or the semantics of Korean language, but the culture of what is currently happening in Korea (ex: fashion and food trends). The many videos we watch and passages we read are a great way to compare our culture with Korea's.

Absolutely!!! Best class I've taken at Yale. So engaging, while still being super informative and conducive to building skills. I loved it. I would say it is accessible to non-heritage speakers too (as long as they are L5, of course).
